course.name: Fundamentals of Business Finance
course.description: For BIBU and non-SB&M students. This course provides an introduction to corporate finance for students who may not have background in accounting and business statistics. Topics include financial statement analysis, time value of money, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return concepts and cost of capital.

reviews.title: Lynn 姐 is grade god
reviews.comment_content:
An introductory corporate finance course. Introduces us through the fundamental concepts of valuation principle, time value of money, investment decision rules, financial statement analysis, capital budgeting, bonds and stocks valuation, and risk/return analysis.

The course content is quite conceptually demanding at first and may make u muddle-headed for quite a bit of time, but after a while u may grasp the concepts better. You may wish to be noted that this course is quantitative and involves quite a lot of formulas. Those who are good at maths can grasp the content more easily.

♦ Introduction to Corporate Finance
♦ Valuation Principle
♦ Time Value of Money
♦ Valuation of Cash Flow Streams
♦ Interest Rates
♦ Investment Decision Rules
♠ Financial Statement Analysis
♠ Fundamentals of Capital Budgeting
♦ Bonds
♦ Stock Valuation
♣️ Risk and Return
♣️ Systematic Risk and Equity Risk Premium
♦ Cost of Capital

♠ Accounting knowledge needed
♣️ Statistics knowledge needed

⚠ Unlike the SBM version of this course (FINA2303), ACCT2010 and ISOM2500 are not explicitly written as prerequisites of this course. However, don't be fooled by such description. This course is actually equivalent to FINA2303 in terms of content and the set of exam papers used, and basic accounting and statistics backgrounds are still crucial to the understanding of the course content. DON'T take this course if you don't haven't learnt these previously, or you'll definitely suffer.

reviews.comment_teaching:
This semester we are having different approach. There will be a routine work for each week: Textbook readings -> VOS (voice-over slides) -> ICA (in-class activity) -> Lesson -> mini-quiz. We have one lesson only every week.

Textbook reading: I don't know it is my problem or not, the textbook is quite difficult to understand and missing reasoning behind formulas. It is important to read the textbook because his notes will not cover all the materials in the book. (They will be examined!)

VOS and lecture notes: Basically VOS  goes through the set of lecture notes for that week. VOS is fine but the lecture notes design is horrible. I do think these notes are made in 1990s. There is no layout, a bunch of irrelevant graphics and "colourful" content. How colourful is that? In week2 material, there couple of slides taking about all the formulas for the ratios. First it is overwhelming. Second, everything is squeeze in one page like it costs him 1million to insert a new slide. (Those formulas are NOT important!)
ALSO HE LOVES SHORT FORM SO MUCH. Let's play a game if you have studied ACCT2010:
Q1: what RV stands for? (Revenue, easy)
Q2: what TX stands for? (Tax)
Q3: what is INT??? (not integer! but interest expense! maybe you will mess up this one with inventory?)
Confusing right?
The first few weeks are all like this :)
Even I got an A in Acct2010, I still suffer from all these mess,

Regular lesson: Something quite nice about this prof is that he plans to have a Portfolio Management Game (PMG) that allows everyone to invest in different stocks in the real world and earn GameCoins. Options like shorting are allowed which is quite fascinating. Every lesson, he will spend some time reviewing the trend of this week. During Chinese New Year he even gives out LaiSee/chocolate coin to the best players or the one actively answering questions. Quite Nice.
There will be an In Class Activity every week and most of them are either case analysis to this week's topic or illustrate some important points in VOS/lecture notes. Overall it is quite good to have his lessons. There will be some IPRS questions for students to win GameCoin for PMG. So no attendance is required.

Mini-quiz: usually mini-quiz consists of basic question or some IPRS question of that week. You will start feeling that some questions are hard to answer, and that is the most difficult part of this course, students admitted to this course are coming from other school like taking business minor or majoring in MAEC/MATH SF track. The math in this course is super easy for us. Therefore, Prof loves those "concept" questions rather than computation. (TA said this)

TA Kenrick is helpful. For those local students who have no accounting background. Attend the optional tutorial and ask Kenrick in Cantonese. The first few chapters will definitely destroy your passion in this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading scheme and my grade will be updated later.
The main purpose I am writing this review is to say something about this "COPY2203" course.
In midterm and final exam, we are having more than enough time to finish 30(midterm) and 40(final) questions. Most of them are T/F or M/C. Both open-book, open-notes and we can access any lecture material in canvas.
AND THIS IS A LOTTERY GAME!
I think he has a "big" question banks that collect so many questions in each topic. When we are doing mini-quizzes, everyone got different sets of questions (reasonable). AND THERE IS A CHANCE THAT YOUR QUESTION APPEARS IN EXAM AGAIN!
What is more interesting is that prof will give an mock midterm/final that consists of the same format as the real exam (guess he is just randomly picking questions from his question bank). If you are lucky enough, you can see those questions appears again in your exams. Therefore, it is like playing a lottery. (sometimes the numerical parameters are the same, sometimes different.)

That make both midterm and final become "Answer searching competition" or "how lucky I am" competition or "Can I find this on textbook" competition. I don't know what I have learnt from this course.
----Update----
Mini-Quiz 12% (best 8 out of 12)
HW 20% (best 4 out of 5)
Midterm 28%
Final 40%
Total (me) : 93.9/100
Final Grade: A
Pretty good grade. Achieving A+ is extremely hard (have to be flawless)
But once again, even I got an A in this course, I can't tell what did I learn.

PRS: Unless you decided to give up the 2% PRS scores, don’t skip lectures even though lecture videos are provided. In this semester, only 6 lectures (after the add/drop period) out of all 23 lectures had PRS sessions. (PRS questions before the add/drop period will not count.) For each PRS session, 2-4 questions will be asked and you will be given 2-3 minutes to answer each question. A total of 19 PRS questions were asked in this semester. The questions are quite challenging. If you miss one PRS session, it would be quite difficult for you to catch up the PRS scores afterwards. Remember to save the PRS questions using the screenshot function of your phone, as these PRS questions are quite useful for your future revision.

MFL Homework: You have to buy the textbook for the access code for the MFL Homework. You have 2 attempts for each question. Try out similar questions on MFL before submitting your homework. The thing I really appreciate is that no homework was due in the midterm break.

Quiz and exams: Going through all tutorial questions and PRS questions is suggested. (I found that a few questions in the quiz had the same style as the PRS questions, see attachment.) If you have time, practice more on MFL. Most questions will require calculations. Formula sheet will be provided (see the 3 attachments). reviews.comment_content:
这门课的内容主要可以分为三个板块
一、 金钱的时间价值 Time Value of Money
二、现金流分析，以及债券、股票的估价（金钱时间价值的具体应用）Cash Flow Analysis, Valuation of Bonds and Stocks
三、风险评估，以及回报率 Risk and Cost of Capital
鉴于其他评论已有对课程内容较详细的描述，我在此不再赘述

我主要讲一下想报这门课的人可能会面临的顾虑：
如果没有会计和数理统计基础，上这门课会吃力吗？
我的答案是不会
这门课的第一部分，金钱的时间价值，完全不需要会计和数理统计的任何知识，只需要会算等比数列 Geometric Series 就足够。第二部分中的现金流分析需要会读现金流量表 Statement of Cash Flows, 但是并不需要很深刻的理解，大概一两个小时就可以完全掌握。第三部分风险评估需要一定的统计背景，涉及到方差 Variance，协方差 Covariance 等内容。但私以为背公式是完全足够应付的，甚至统计公式会直接打印在试卷上。
我在上这门课之前只上过ISOM2500，在上这门FINA2203的同时也在上着ACCT2010，总体感到轻松愉悦，没有很吃力的地方。

reviews.comment_content:
First of all, I have never studied in any other business courses before. I have zero background about it (pure science background). However, I think this course is not too difficult for those who has no business background before (as long as you work on it!).

It is quite normal that you feel confused about the terms and concepts as you begin to learn it but trust me, you can get through it before midterm!

The structure of this course is based on 'week', for each week, a new chapter was learnt (except week 4 and 5, which focused on ch4 only). So there were 11 chapters covered. These 11 chapters come from textbook 'Corporate Finance: Core Principles and Applications (6th edition)', it is a must to buy it cuz you gonna do homework in it's connect system.

This course basically teaches you how to read balance sheet and income statement, how to extract info from these statements, the concept of Cash Flow, stocks and bonds, to see how a much a company worth, how money depreciate as time gone by (most important concept through the course!), how to buy stocks etc. You'll encounter a lot of calculation stuff + conceptual stuff. Good news: chapters are coherent so you can consolidate your learning as you work through it.

Here's the outline:
Week 1: chapter 1: Introduction to Corporate Finance

Week 2: Chapter 3: Financial Statement Analysis & Financial Models

Week 3: Chapter 2: Financial Statements & Cash Flow

Week 4: Chapter 4: Discounted Cash Flow Valuation

Week 5: Chapter 4: Discounted Cash Flow Valuation

Week 6: Chapter 5: Interest Rates and Bond Valuation

Week 7: Midterm (21/3)

Week 8: Chapter 6: Stock Valuation

Week 9: Chapter 7: Net Present Value and Other Investment Rules

Week 10: Chapter 8: Making Capital Investment Decisions

Week 11: Midterm break

Week 12: Chapter 11: Return and Risk: The Capital Asset Pricing Model

Week 13: Chapter 12: Risk, Cost of Capital, and Capital Budgeting

Final Exam (23/5)

By the way, besides ordinary lecture stuff, they also provided a 'game': Portfolio Management Game. It is just a stock market simulation, if you buy good stocks, you'll earn game coins. Besides, doing good in weekly quizzes and in-class polling iPRS can also increase game coins.

Game coins can in turn help you with you your mini quizzes result if you earn a lot of it. (Yes! So if you do well in mini quizzes, you earn more game coins, more game coins help you do better in mini quizzes, positive cycle!)

This course's performance mainly depends on your after class self-study effort, so make sure you have enough time to invest in it if you want to get a good grade.

reviews.comment_content:
The content of this course is divided into 3 main parts:
1. time value of money (PV,FV,PMT,I)
2. capital budgeting
3. risk and return

As long as you have build up a good foundation in these concepts, you will have no problem understanding the worked examples as well as the narrower concepts established from the main parts. Having a good understanding of the lecture notes provided should be enough to get you a B or above. It's rather difficult to get A range unless you put in a lot of effort in reading the textbook and understanding every solution to the homework.
